source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: At low applied stresses (that is, below the unirradiated flow stress of wellannealed material) he suggested [4] that the creep is primarily due to the stress-induced preferred orientation and growth of vacancy or interstitial loops or both.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: At somewhat higher stresses the creep rate is believed to be controlled by the glide and climb of edge dislocations [4].

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: The primary obstacles to the glide of dislocations, after moderate radiation exposures (at temperatures $< 0 . 3 ~ T _ { m }$ ) are believed to be the radiation-produced depleted zones [7].

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: At stresses up to the post-irradiation-hardened flow stress, the creep rate is controlled by climb to escape the depleted zones

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: at higher stresses the creep rate is controlled by cutting through the depleted zones

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: At stresses near the unirradiated flow stress for well-annealed material Nichols proposed [4] that the creep rate is controlled by glide between the depleted zones

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: Dollins [9] proposed a hightemperature theory which allowed vacancy boil-off and migration as well as interstitial migration and his model is consequently applicable in the temperature range of most interest for the creep of structural materials in operating reactors

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: The pinned dislocations can escape the zones by (1) climbing out of them by absorption of neutron-produced point defects, (2) the dissolution of the zones either by absorption of neutron-produced interstitials or by vacancy emission, and (3) by thermally activated cutting of the zones

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: At low temperatures $( T \ < 0 . 0 8 \ T _ { m } )$ field ion microscopy indicates that the damage regions contain typically $\gtrsim ~ 1 0$ percent vacancies

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: At somewhat higher temperatures $( \sim 0 . 1 2 ~ T _ { m }$ ) Hudson et al observed clusters that gave a void-like contrast

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk2
evidence_span: at temperatures of interest $( \sim 3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ for creep in zirconium-base alloys the damage would consist of spherical voids and isolated interstitials with very few isolated vacancies

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk3
evidence_span: The creep rate depends both on the density of depleted zones and on the time necessary for dislocations to climb and escape them.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk3
evidence_span: Before the damage saturates there are far more interstitials produced than single vacancies.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk3

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk3

evidence_span: Harkness et al assumed that the dislocation has a larger capture radius for interstitials than for vacancies whereas Dollins assumed the capture radius the same for both defects

evidence_span: observable creep rates can be explained by a difference of only O.1 to l percent between the arrival rates of vacancies and interstitials at the dislocation

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk6
evidence_span: Figure 5 shows the predicted dependence of the creep rate on the temperature for several different neutron fluxes. At high temperatures the predicted strain rate increases rapidly with temperature due to a rapid decrease with temperature in the depleted zone density and increased self-diffusion. At temperatures below about 300°C the zone density and hence creep rate are very little dependent upon temperature.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_023_chunk6
evidence_span: Also shown in Fig. 5 are creep data of Fidleris [28] for Zr-2.5Nb alloys irradiated with a fast neutron flux between 5 and 9×10¹² n/cm²/s, the RX-13 data were obtained at an applied stress of 24 000 psi, and the RX-23 data were obtained at an applied stress of 21 000 psi.
